steps.text: Identify potential risks in business operations.
Identify, analyze, assess, and process organizational risks.
Identify potential risks and their interconnections.
Perform business continuity planning.
Transfer risks through subcontracting or insurance.
Entrepreneur remains responsible according to insurance terms and safety regulations.
Company management is responsible for safety.
Issue clear instructions.
Supervise compliance.
Identify potential fire risks in working machines.
Evaluate each machine's operating environment.
Assess potential risk of personal injury from fire.
Check operating conditions and environment for normalcy.
Avoid using fireworks in dangerous environments or for other purposes.
Consider the operating environment when assessing fire risk.
Consider impact on the company's other risks in assessing fire risks.
Use tools to help assess the risk of fire.
Determine the level of risk for the company.
Identify employee actions in an accident scenario.
Assess adequacy of preventive maintenance for business continuity.
Evaluate fire risk management in daily work.
Begin operation of a working machine.
Monitor machine for signs of overheating, leaks, or electrical issues.
Maintain high-quality service.
Use first-aid extinguishing equipment if a fire occurs.
Perform scheduled maintenance according to manufacturer's instructions.
Participate in manufacturer recall campaigns.
Use authentic replacement parts.
Obtain parts from known manufacturers.
Inspect and clean the engine compartment and surroundings when operating in dusty or fire-hazard conditions.
Inspect and clean at least once a week in other environments.
Clean using compressed air.
Inspect for leaks.
Keep engine compartment clean.
Avoid letting flammable liquids reach hot surfaces.
Check joints of hoses and pipes.
Inspect engine compartment for oil leaks.
Protect hydraulic hoses from high temperatures.
Use thermal shields or tubes for hoses near hot surfaces.
Repair any hydraulic hose leaks immediately.
Visually inspect electrical systems annually.
Document inspections.
Inspect electrical systems.
Use a multimeter to measure voltage drops.
Record voltage measurements.
Use a thermal imaging camera to detect anomalies.
Compare readings with an intact machine.
Locate main power switch outside engine compartment for machines over 500 kg.
Visibly mark the main power switch.
Install terminal covers on switch poles.
Locate and operate emergency kill switch.
Confirm power is cut off.
Shut down the engine.
Cut power.
Repair any malfunction.
Do not use it for a normal shutdown.
Repair any deviations immediately.
Check that cable terminals are intact.
Attach cable terminals firmly.
Install terminal covers.
Ensure battery compartment has sufficient ventilation.
Check cables not protected by a fuse.
Examine lead-throughs for rubber collars.
Replace cables with signs of abrasion or heat damage.
Protect them with a housing pipe.
Keep cables clean of oil and dirt.
Do not attach them to hoses or pipes.
Protect cable harnesses.
Firmly attach cable harnesses.
Make cable connections tight.
Install terminal covers on cable connections.
Check the electric panel during maintenance.
Repair any redundant or hanging wires.
Ensure fuse boxes are intact and have lids.
Check that fuses are the correct size.
Investigate the cause of any blown fuse.
Fasten cables with brackets no more than 150 mm apart.
Use fasteners and cable ties that can withstand temperatures of 120°C.
Do not attach cables to flammable material pipes or hoses.
Attach alternator firmly with correct belt tension and install terminal covers.
Keep alternator filter clean to prevent overheating.
Check for anomalies with a thermal camera.
Check fasteners.
Check belts.
Check bearings.
Replace noisy bearings.
Check exhaust pipe for leaks and ensure thermal shields are in place.
Keep flammable liquid hoses away from each other.
Maintain safe distance for urea systems and diesel particulate filters.
Take care to prevent contamination during refuelling.
The diesel particulate filter is cleaned via regeneration.
Check machine indication for regeneration.
Perform regeneration in a safe outdoor environment.
Avoid flammable materials during regeneration.
Monitor regeneration process.
Check for fire hazards before starting the process.
Delay the process if machine is in a fire-hazard environment (e.g., underground, indoors).
Do not leave the machine unattended during regeneration.
Inspect all hoses and electrical systems in the swivelling joint.
Remove any rocks or twigs found.
Make sure all operating manuals are accessible in the machine.
Check that operating manuals are in a language the operator understands.
Check cleanliness and condition of auxiliary heater.
Inspect heater compartment for fuel leaks.
Inspect the heater's exhaust pipe to ensure it doesn't touch anything flammable.
Test the heater under supervision before use.
Machines with a weight greater than 3,000 kg require at least two hand-held fire extinguishers.
Install frost-resistant liquid-based extinguishers with the type code 34A233B.
Machines require four 34A233B extinguishers.
Extinguishers are to be made available at ground level.
Extinguishers must be easily accessible.
Extinguishers need clear marking.
Extinguishers require annual servicing.
Operators must be trained.
Autonomous machines must have a fixed fire extinguishing system.
Protect hot components, flammable liquid hoses/tanks, and electrical components.
The system requires six litres of agent per protected cubic metre.
Cover entire engine compartment with detection system.
Protect hydraulic hoses in engine compartment with thermal protection tubes.
Machines in dust or fire hazard environments require a fixed, fully automatic fire extinguishing system.
Install the required fire extinguishing system.
Ensure there is at least three litres of extinguishing agent for every cubic meter of engine or heater compartment.
Install detection system that covers the entire engine compartment and connect it to non-fused cables.
Install the certificate.
Obtain a test report for compliance.
Confirm system operation at start-up.
Repair any malfunctions.
Service the system at least once a year.
Clean engine compartments daily.
Mark fire extinguishing openings.
Choose approved extinguisher suppliers.
Inspect fire safety forms.
Check signs and markings.
Inspect machine electrical systems.
Examine engine mechanics.
Inspect first-aid extinguishing equipment.
Check auxiliary heater installation.
Inspect mains power systems.
Assess general condition and cleanliness.
In case of engine fire, use approved extinguisher.
Remain calm.
Shut down the engine.
Move the machine indoors to outdoors.
Move the machine away from flammable material.
Cut electricity from the main power switch.
Turn off electricity.
Call for help.
Use the 112 smartphone app if possible.
Perform first-aid fire extinguishing.
Confirm the fire is out with the fire department.
Report the incident to the safety officer, site manager, coworkers, and insurance company.
Report all accidents and dangerous situations to a supervisor immediately.
Stop the machine.
Leave the machine in place.
Wear protective clothing and a helmet.
Use a hands-free device for phone calls.
Wear a safety belt.
Use stepladders and handrails.
Maintain three points of contact when climbing.
Keep doors closed during operation.
Ensure tools are secure.
Mark emergency exits.
Repair any malfunctions that could lead to an accident.
Arrange practical training on accident and fire procedures.
Check cables for security.
Examine fasteners for heat resistance.
Inspect cables for insulation.
Verify lead-throughs.
Inspect condition of non-fused cables.
Examine terminal covers.
Check cleanliness of engine and heater compartments.
Look for leaks in engine and heater compartments.
Identify the location of the first-aid extinguishing equipment.
Check the availability and markings of the equipment.
Ensure operator training for using the equipment.

constraints.text: Using fireworks in dangerous environments or for other purposes heightens risks.
The operating environment affects the potential impact of a fire.
Flammable liquids can ignite when hot surfaces reach about 240°C.
Voltage drop exceeding 20W indicates an increased fire risk.
Terminal covers prevent overheating.
Battery compartment requires sufficient ventilation.
* Urea systems and diesel particulate filter: Urea systems do not pose a fire risk, but leaks can cause corrosion and disrupt electrical equipment.
Perform regeneration in a safe outdoor environment away from flammable materials.
Machine should not be in a fire-hazard environment during the process.
Do not leave machine unattended during regeneration.
Ensure availability and comprehension of manuals for safe operation and malfunction handling, which may indicate a fire hazard.
Heater compartment must be clean and free of fuel leaks.
Extinguishers are to be available, clearly marked, and serviced at least annually.
Machines in dust or fire hazard environments must have a fixed, fully automatic fire extinguishing system.
Finance Finland (FFI) and Pohjola Insurance have specific requirements for fire extinguishing systems in working machines.
Requirements for extinguishing agent and detection system.
Engine compartment coverage and non-fused cable connection for detection system.
Installation requires a certificate and compliance requires a test report.
Repair any malfunctions immediately by an authorized shop.
Check and address potential hazards before shutting down.
